abandon.descriptionFr: Abandon (F) is a noun that means abandonment, desertion, neglect, or giving up. It can also mean abandon, especially with a verb: danser avec abandon = to dance with abandon. Abandonner = to abandon.

action.descriptionFr: Action (F) can mean action as well as act or a share of stock.

addition.descriptionFr: Addition (F) can refer to addition, a sum, or a restaurant check or bill.
addition.descriptionEn: Addition (E) = une addition, une augmentation, or un surcroît.

ado.descriptionFr: Ado (F) is an apocope of adolescent—teen or teenager.
ado.descriptionEn: Ado (E) is a somewhat rare word that is equivalent to agitation or bruit (figuratively)

affluence.descriptionFr: Affluence (F) is a crowd of people: Il y avait une affluence attendant à la porte = There were crowds waiting at the door.
affluence.descriptionEn: Affluence (E) indicates a lot of something (usually wealth): There's an affluence of information here = Il y a une abondance d'information ici. His affluence is obvious = Sa richesse est évidente.

agenda.descriptionEn: Agenda (E) means l'ordre du jour or le programme.

allure.descriptionFr: Allure (F) normally refers to speed or pace: Rouler à toute allure = to drive at full speed. It can also refer to an appearance or look. Allures refers to behavior or ways.

amateur.descriptionFr: Amateur (F) is a semi-false cognate. It can mean amateur in the sense of non-professional, but it can also mean a lover of something: un amateur d'art = an art lover.
amateur.descriptionEn: Amateur (E) refers to someone who dabbles in a trade or activity: an amateur photographer: un amateur de photographie.

animation.descriptionFr: Animation (F) is much more general in French than in English. In addition to animation, life, liveliness, it can also refer to cultural or sports activities as well as leadership.

antique.descriptionFr: Antique (F) as an adjective means antique or ancient. As a noun, it refers to antiquity or classical art/style.
antique.descriptionEn: Antique (E) means the same an adjective, but as a noun it refers to une antiquité, un objet d'art ancien, or un meuble ancien.

are.descriptionFr: Are (F) refers to an area of one hundred square meters.
are.descriptionEn: Are (E) is a conjugation of "to be" (être): we are (nous sommes), you are (vous êtes), they are (ils sont).

argument.descriptionFr: Argument (F) is a semi-false cognate. It means argument in the sense of a mathematical or philosophical argument. Also: argument massue = sledgehammer blow; argument publicitaire = advertising claim; argument de vente = selling point.
argument.descriptionEn: Argument (E) is une discussion, une conversation, un débat, or une dispute.

assistance.descriptionFr: Assistance (F) is a semi-false cognate. Its primary meaning is audience.

assurance.descriptionFr: Assurance (F) refers to self-confidence or insurance in addition to assurance.

audience.descriptionFr: Audience (F) is a semi-false cognate. In addition to the meaning of the English word, it can signify: Votre audience, s'il vous plaît = Your attention, please. Ce projet a une large audience - This project has a lot of attention. Donner audience à quelqu'un = To meet with / listen to someone. Une audience publique = A public meeting.
audience.descriptionEn: Audience (E) is a group of spectators or listeners.

bra.descriptionFr: The French bra (F) is a limb on the human body and the opposite of jambe ("leg").
bra.descriptionEn: A "bra" (E) in English is, of course, a female undergarment, but the French call this garment, appropriately, a support (un soutien-gorge).

brassiere.descriptionFr: A French brasserie is an institution in France, a place, much like the British pub, where you'd find a bar that serves meals, or a brewery.
brassiere.descriptionEn: No connection to the female undergarment in the English word "brassiere," of which "bra" is the abbreviated form.

blessed.descriptionFr: If someone is blessé in France, they are wounded, emotionally or physically.
blessed.descriptionEn: This is far from the English "blessed," which can apply to a religious sacrament or just great luck.

button.descriptionFr: Bouton does mean button in French, as it does in English, but a French bouton can also refer to that bane of the teenage years: a pimple.

confection.descriptionFr: La confection (F) refers to the making or preparing of clothing, a device, a meal, and more. It can also refer to the clothing industry.
confection.descriptionEn: An English confection (E) is a class of food that's sweet, something that's made in a bakery or candy shop.

exposition.descriptionFr: Une exposition (F) can refer to an exposition of facts, as well as to an exhibition or show, the aspect of a building, or exposure to heat or radiation.
exposition.descriptionEn: An English "exposition" is a commentary or or an essay developing a point of view.

grand.descriptionFr: Grand is a very, very common French word for big, but there are times it refers to something or someone great, such as un grand homme or a grand-père. When it describes a person’s physical appearance, it means tall.
grand.descriptionEn: "Grand" in English commonly refers to a special human being, thing, or place of notable achievement.

implantation.descriptionFr: Une implantation is the introduction or setting up of a new method or industry, a settlement, or a company's presence in a country or region. Medically, the French terms means implantation (of an organ or embryo).
implantation.descriptionEn: An English implantation is an implantation only in the sense of an introduction or setting up or in the medical sense.

justice.descriptionFr: French justesse is all about exactness, accuracy, correctness, soundness, and the like. If something is juste, it is corect. The English "justice" refers to what we expect when the rule of law prevails: justice.

location.descriptionFr: There are miles between these two meanings. A French location is a rental, and you'll often see ads for “les meilleures locations de vacances,” meaning “the best holiday rentals.”
location.descriptionEn: "Location" is the physical spot where something like a building lives, you know: location, location, location, which can be important in finding a French location.

vicious.descriptionFr: The French term vicieux (F) gives us pause because it's what you call someone perverted, depraved, or nasty.
vicious.descriptionEn: In English, the "vicious" person is brutal, but not quite so nasty as a vicieux in French.

education.descriptionFr: éducation (F) usually refers to education at home: upbringing, manners.
education.descriptionEn: education (E) is a general term for formal learning = instruction, enseignement.

eligible.descriptionFr: éligible (F) means eligible only for membership or an elected office.
eligible.descriptionEn: eligible (E) is a much more general term: éligible or admissible. To be eligible = avoir droit à, remplir/satisfaire les conditions requises pour.

email.descriptionEn: email (E) is often translated as un email, but the accepted French term is un courriel (learn more).

embarrass.descriptionFr: embarras (F) indicates trouble or confusion as well as embarrassment.
embarrass.descriptionEn: embarrass (E) is a verb: embarrasser, gêner.

embrace.descriptionFr: embrasser (F) means to kiss, or can be used formally to mean to espouse.

emergency.descriptionFr: émergence (F) is the equivalent of the English words emergence or source.
emergency.descriptionEn: emergency (E) is un cas urgent or un imprévu.

employer.descriptionFr: employer (F) is a verb - to use, employ.
employer.descriptionEn: employer (E) is a noun - un patron, un employeur.

enchanted.descriptionFr: enchanté (F) means enchanted or delighted, and is most commonly used upon meeting someone, the way "It's nice to meet you" is used in English.
enchanted.descriptionEn: enchanted (E) = enchanté, but the English word is much less common than the French.

infant.descriptionEn: Infant (E) refers to un nouveau-né or un bébé.

engagement.descriptionFr: engagement (F) has many meanings: commitment, promise, agreement; (finance) investing, liabilities; (negotiations) opening, start; (sports) kick-off; (contest) entry. It never means a marital engagement.
engagement.descriptionEn: engagement (E) usually indicates one's engagement to be married: les fiançailles. It can also refer to un rendez-vous or une obligation.

engross.descriptionFr: engrosser (F) is a familiar verb meaning to knock up, get someone pregnant.

enthusiast.descriptionFr: enthousiaste (F) can be a noun - enthusiast, or an adjective - enthusiastic.
enthusiast.descriptionEn: enthusiast (E) is only a noun - enthousiaste.

entr\u00e9e.descriptionFr: entrée (F) is another word for hors-d'oeuvre; an appetizer.
entr\u00e9e.descriptionEn: entrée (E) refers to the main course of a meal: le plat principal.

escrow.descriptionFr: escroc (F) refers to a crook or swindler.
escrow.descriptionEn: escrow (E) means un dépôt fiduciaire or conditionnel.

etiquette.descriptionFr: étiquette (F) is a semi-false cognate. In addition to etiquette or protocole, it can be a sticker or label.
etiquette.descriptionEn: etiquette (E) can mean étiquette, convenances, or protocole.

eventual.descriptionFr: éventuel (F) means possible: le résultat éventuel - the possible outcome.
eventual.descriptionEn: eventual (E) describes something that will happen at some unspecified point in the future; it can be translated by a relative clause like qui s'ensuit or qui a résulté or by an adverb like finalement.

evidence.descriptionFr: évidence (F) refers to obviousness, an obvious fact, or prominence.
evidence.descriptionEn: evidence (E) means le témoignage or la preuve.

evident.descriptionFr: évident (F) usually means evident or obvious, and there is a familiar expression that always catches me: ce n'est pas évident - it's not that simple.

evince.descriptionFr: évincer (F) means to oust, supplant, or evict.
evince.descriptionEn: evince (E) = manifester or faire preuve de.

exceptional.descriptionFr: exceptionnel (F) can mean either exceptional or special in the sense of out-of-the-ordinary, unexpected.

experiment.descriptionFr: expérimenter (F) is a semi-false cognate. It is equivalent to the English verb, but also has the added sense of to test an apparatus.
experiment.descriptionEn: experiment (E) as a verb means to test hypotheses or ways of doing things. As a noun, it is equivalent to the French word expérience (see above).

exploitation.descriptionFr: exploitation (F) can mean either usage or exploitation.
exploitation.descriptionEn: exploitation (E) is translated by exploitation, but it always has a negative connotation in English, unlike the French which can simply refer to usage.

extra.descriptionFr: extra (F) is an adjective that means first-rate or terrific. Un extra is a catering assistant or a treat.
extra.descriptionEn: extra (E) the adjective means supplémentaire. As an adverb, it might be translated by plus, très, or even un supplément (e.g., to pay extra - payer un supplément). As a noun meaning "perk," it's equivalent to un à-côté. extras as in "extra options" are en option or gâteries, "extra fees" are frais supplémentaires. An acting extra is un figurant and extra time in sports is prolongation(s).

icy.descriptionEn: icy (E) means glacial, glacé, or verglacé.

ideology.descriptionFr: idéologie (F) can refer to an ideology, but is usually used in a pejorative sense: ideology or philosophy based on sophomoric or illogical arguments.

ignorant.descriptionFr: ignorant (F) is a semi-false cognate. It usually means unaware of, although it can mean ignorant (E). It can also be a noun - ignoramus.
ignorant.descriptionEn: ignorant (E) has only one French equivalent - ignorant, but in English it is usually somewhat pejorative: lacking education or knowledge. The French word ignorant doesn't distinguish between unaware and uneducated.

impair.descriptionFr: impair (F) is an adjective: odd or uneven.
impair.descriptionEn: impair (E) is a verb: diminuer or affaiblir.

important.descriptionFr: important (F) has a much broader meaning that its English cognate. In addition to important in the sense of significant or authoritative, important (F) can also mean large, considerable, substantial.

imposition.descriptionFr: imposition (F) refers to taxation (les impôts - taxes). In religion, l'imposition des mains = the laying on of hands.
imposition.descriptionEn: imposition (E) has two distinct meanings. The imposition of something, such as a regulation, is la mise en place. In the sense of a burden, imposition can't be translated by a noun. The sentence needs to be rewritten using a verb like abuser or déranger to get the sense of imposition across.

inconvenient.descriptionFr: inconvénient (F) is a noun and is also somewhat stronger than the English word inconvenient; un inconvénient is a disadvantage, drawback, or risk.

inconsistent.descriptionFr: inconsistant (F) indicates poor consistency: flimsy, weak, colorless, runny, or watery. In a more general sense, it can be translated by inconsistent.
inconsistent.descriptionEn: inconsistent (E) means lacking consistency or being erratic: inconséquent, incompatible.

index.descriptionFr: index (F) can refer to the index finger, a pointer, or an alphabetical index.
index.descriptionEn: index (E) is an alphabetical index or table. When it is used in statistics, the French equivalent is une indice.

infect.descriptionFr: infect (F) is an adjective: revolting, obnoxious, squalid, vile, horrible.
infect.descriptionEn: infect (E) is a verb: infecter, contaminer.

information.descriptionFr: information (F) is a semi-false cognate. Une information refers to a single piece of information, while des informations is equivalent to the general English term information. In addition, une information can indicate an official inquiry or investigation.
information.descriptionEn: information (E) means des renseignements or informations.

inform.descriptionEn: inform (E) can mean informer, avertir, aviser, or renseigner.

ingrate.descriptionFr: ingrat (F) can be an adjective - ungrateful, bleak, unreliable, or unattractive - or a noun: ingrate, ungrateful person.

injury.descriptionFr: injure (F) is an insult or term of abuse.

inscription.descriptionFr: inscription (F) is a true cognate in the sense of text inscriptions. However, it is also a general term for action as well as registration or enrollment.
inscription.descriptionEn: inscription (E) = une inscription on a coin or monument, or une dédicace in a book.

instance.descriptionFr: instance (F) means authority, official proceedings, or insistence.
instance.descriptionEn: instance (E) refers to something that is representative of a group, an example - un exemple.

integral.descriptionFr: intégral (F) means complete, unabridged, or total.

interesting.descriptionFr: intéressant (F) is a semi-false cognate. In addition to interesting, it can mean attractive, worthwhile, or favorable (e.g., a price or offer).
interesting.descriptionEn: interesting (E) means captivating, worth looking at, etc.

introduce.descriptionFr: introduire (F) means to place, insert, or introduce into. It is not used in the sense of introducing one person to another.

invite.descriptionFr: inviter (F) means both to invite and to treat (someone to a meal/drink).

fabric.descriptionFr: Fabrique (F) is a factory. De bonne fabrique means good workmanship.
fabric.descriptionEn: Fabric (E) is equivalent to tissu or étoffe. When speaking figuratively, e.g., the fabric of society, the French word is structure.

facility.descriptionFr: Facilité (F) means ease, easiness, ability, or aptitude.
facility.descriptionEn: Facility (E) is a semi-false cognate. It usually refers to a structure that serves a particular function, although it can mean easiness, aptitude, etc.

fashion.descriptionFr: Façon (F) means way, as in voilà la façon dont il procède - this is the way he does it. It can be translated by fashion when it is synonymous with way or manner, as in à ma façon - in my fashion / my way.
fashion.descriptionEn: Fashion (E) is a style or custom, usually in clothing: mode or vogue. For all of you apple pie eaters out there, now you know that à la mode really means in fashion.

factor.descriptionFr: Facteur (F) is a semi-false cognate. In addition to factor, it can mean postman, mailman, or maker - un facteur de pianos - piano maker.
factor.descriptionEn: Factor (E) = un facteur, un élément, un indice.

fastidious.descriptionFr: Fastidieux (F) means tedious, tiresome, or boring
fastidious.descriptionEn: Fastidious (E) means attentive to detail or exacting: minutieux, méticuleux, tatillon.

fend.descriptionFr: Fendre (F) means to split or to chop.
fend.descriptionEn: Fend (E) is se débrouiller, to fend off means parer or détourner.

figure.descriptionFr: Figure (F) is a semi-false cognate. It is the French word for face, but can also refer to an illustrated or mathematical figure.
figure.descriptionEn: Figure (E) refers to numbers chiffres as well as to the form of a person's body: forme, silhouette.

file.descriptionFr: File (F) is a line or queue. Filer (F) means to spin (e.g., cotton or thread) or to prolong.
file.descriptionEn: File (E) can refer to une lime (as well as the verb limer), un dossier, or un classeur (and the verb classer).

film.descriptionEn: Film (E) can mean un film as well as la pellicule.

phlegm.descriptionFr: Flemme (F) is an informal word for laziness. It's commonly used in the expressions "avoir la flemme" (J'ai la flemme d'y aller - I can't be bothered to go) and "tirer sa flemme" - to loaf about.

flirt.descriptionFr: Flirter (F) may mean to flirt or to go out with/date someone.
flirt.descriptionEn: Flirt (E) is flirter or, informally, draguer.

fluid.descriptionFr: Fluide (F) can be a noun: fluid, or an adjective: fluid, flowing, flexible. Il a du fluide - He has mysterious powers.

fond.descriptionFr: Fond (F) is a noun: bottom or back.
fond.descriptionEn: Fond (E) is an adjective: to be fond of - aimer beaucoup, avoir de l'affection pour.

football.descriptionFr: Football (F) or le foot, refers to soccer (in American English).

forcefully.descriptionEn: Forcefully (E) can be translated by avec force or avec vigueur.

forfeit.descriptionFr: Forfait (F) is a fixed, set, or all-inclusive price; a package deal; or, in sports, a withdrawal.
forfeit.descriptionEn: Forfeit (E) as a noun indicates un prix, une peine, or un dédit.

formation.descriptionFr: Formation (F) refers to training as well as formation/forming.

format.descriptionEn: Format (E) as a noun refers to présentation; as a verb it means formater or mettre en forme.

formal.descriptionFr: Formel (F) usually means categoric, strict, or definite, but may be translated by formal in linguistics, art, and philosophy.

formidable.descriptionFr: Formidable (F) is an interesting word, because it means great or terrific; almost the opposite of the English. Ce film est formidable ! - This is a great movie!
formidable.descriptionEn: Formidable (E) means dreadful or fearsome: The opposition is formidable - L'opposition est redoutable/effrayante.

fort.descriptionFr: Fort (F) is an adjective: strong or loud as well as a noun - fort.
fort.descriptionEn: Fort (E) refers to un fort or fortin.

four.descriptionFr: Four (F) is an oven, kiln, or furnace.

furniture.descriptionEn: It's from the verb fournir: to supply or provide.

foyer.descriptionFr: Foyer (F) can mean home, family, or fireplace as well as a foyer.
foyer.descriptionEn: Foyer (E) is un foyer, un hall, or un vestibule.

fresh.descriptionFr: fraîche (F) is the feminine form of the adjective frais, which means both fresh and cool. So this tends to be problem for native French speakers, who often translate boissons fraîches as "fresh drinks," when what they really mean is cool drinks.

friction.descriptionFr: Friction (F) can refer to a massage in addition to friction.

frond.descriptionFr: Fronde (F) is a sling, slingshot, or catapult; a revolt; or a frond.
frond.descriptionEn: Frond (E) = une fronde or une feuille.

front.descriptionFr: Front (F) means front as well as forehead.

futile.descriptionFr: Futile (F) can mean futile but is more likely to be frivolous or trivial.
futile.descriptionEn: Futile (E) is nearly always translated by vain.

bless.descriptionFr: Blesser means to wound, injure, or offend

character.descriptionFr: Caractère refers only to the character or temperament of a person or thing: Cette maison a du caractère - This house has character.
character.descriptionEn: Character can mean both nature/temperament as well as a person in a play: Education develops character - L'éducation développe le caractère, Romeo is a famous character - Romeo est un personnage célebre

cent.descriptionFr: Cent is the French word for a hundred
cent.descriptionEn: cent in English can be figuratively translated by un sou. Literally, it is one-hundredth of a dollar.

chair.descriptionEn: A chair can refer to une chaise, un fauteuil (armchair), or un siège (seat).

chance.descriptionEn: chance in English refers to un hasard, une possibilité, or une occasion. To say "I didn't have a chance to..."

christian.descriptionFr: Christian is a masculine French name
christian.descriptionEn: Christian in English can be an adjective or a noun: (un) chrétien.

coin.descriptionFr: Le coin refers to a corner in every sense of the English word. It can also be used figuratively to mean from the area: l'épicier du coin - the local grocer
coin.descriptionEn: A coin is a piece of metal used as money - une pièce de monnaie.

college.descriptionFr: Le collège and le lycée both refer to high school: Mon collège a 1 000 élèves - My high school has 1,000 students
college.descriptionEn: College is translated by université: This college's tuition is very expensive - Les frais de scolarité à cette université sont très élevés.

command.descriptionFr: Commande is a semi-false cognate. It is an order (request) a meal or goods/services. Une commande is translated by order in English.
command.descriptionEn: Command can be translated by un ordre or un commandement.

commander.descriptionFr: Commander is a semi-false cognate. It means to make an order (command) as well as to order (request) a meal or goods/services. Une commande is translated by order in English.
commander.descriptionEn: Commander is someone that gives orders. It can be translated by commandant.

con.descriptionFr: Con is a vulgar word that literally refers to female genitalia. It usually means an idiot, or is used as an adjective in the sense of bloody or damned.
con.descriptionEn: Con can be a noun - la frime, une escroquerie, or a verb - duper, escroquer. Pros and cons - le pour et le contre

crayon.descriptionFr: Un crayon is a pencil, the French language uses this expression for both crayon and colored pencil.
crayon.descriptionEn: A crayon is as un crayon de couleur.

deception.descriptionFr: Une déception is a disappointment or let-down.
deception.descriptionEn: A deception is une tromperie or duperie.

demand.descriptionFr: Demander means to ask for: Il m'a demandé de chercher son pull - He asked me to look for his sweater. Note that the French noun une demande does correspond to the English noun demand.
demand.descriptionEn: To demand is usually translated by exiger: He demanded that I look for his sweater - Il a exigé que je cherche son pull

derange.descriptionFr: Déranger can mean to derange (the mind), as well as to bother, disturb, or disrupt. Excusez-moi de vous déranger... - I'm sorry for bothering you....
derange.descriptionEn: To derange is used only when talking about mental health (usually as an adjective: deranged = dérangé).

douche.descriptionEn: Douche in English refers to a method of cleaning a body cavity with air or water: lavage interne.

gentle.descriptionFr: Gentil usually means nice or kind: Il a un gentil mot pour chacun - He has a kind word for everyone. It can also mean good, as in: il a été gentil - he was a good boy
gentle.descriptionEn: Gentle can also mean kind but in the more physical sense of soft or not rough. It can be translated by doux, aimable, modéré, or léger: He is gentle with his hands - Il a la main douce. A gentle breeze - une  brise légère

gratuity.descriptionFr: Gratuité refers to anything that is given for free: la gratuité de l'éducation - free education
gratuity.descriptionEn: while a gratuity is un pourboire or une gratification.

gross.descriptionFr: Gros means big, fat, heavy, or serious: un gros problème - a big/serious problem
gross.descriptionEn: Gross means grossier, fruste, or (informally) dégueullasse.

napkin.descriptionFr: Un napkin refers to a sanitary napkin.
napkin.descriptionEn: A napkin is correctly translated by une serviette.

occasion.descriptionFr: Occasion refers to a(n) occasion, circumstance, opportunity, or second-hand purchase. Avoir l'occasion de means to have a/the chance to: Je n'avais pas l'occasion de lui parler - I didn't have a chance to talk to him.
occasion.descriptionEn: An occasion is une occasion, un événement, or un motif.

opportunity.descriptionFr: Opportunité refers to timeliness or appropriateness: Nous discutons de l'opportunité d'aller à la plage - We're discussing the appropriateness of going to the beach (under the circumstances).
opportunity.descriptionEn: Opportunity leans toward favorable circumstances for a particular action or event and is translated by une occasion: It's an opportunity to improve your French - C'est une occasion de te perfectionner en français.

party.descriptionFr: Une partie can mean a part (e.g., une partie du film - a part of the film), a field or subject, a game (e.g., une partie de cartes - a game of cards), or a party in a trial.
party.descriptionEn: A party usually refers to une fête, soirée, or réception; un correspondant (on the phone), or un groupe/une équipe.

piece.descriptionFr: Une pièce is a semi-false cognate. It means piece only in the sense of broken pieces. Otherwise, it indicates a room, sheet of paper, coin, or play.
piece.descriptionEn: Piece is a part of something - un morceau or une tranche.

professor.descriptionFr: Un professeur refers to a high school, college, or university teacher or instructor.
professor.descriptionEn: A professor is un professeur titulaire d'une chaire.

publicity.descriptionFr: Publicité is a semi-false cognate. In addition to publicity, une publicité can mean advertising in general, as well as a commercial or advertisement.
publicity.descriptionEn: Publicity is translated by de la publicité.

quit.descriptionFr: Quitter is a semi-false cognate: it means both to leave and to quit (i.e., leave something for good).
quit.descriptionEn: When quit means to leave something for good, it is translated by quitter. When it means to quit (stop) doing something, it is translated by arrêter de: I need to quit smoking - Je dois arrêter de fumer.

rate.descriptionFr: Rater means to misfire, miss, mess up, or fail.
rate.descriptionEn: Rate is the noun proportion or taux or the verb évaluer or considérer.

realize.descriptionFr: Réaliser means to fulfill (a dream or aspiration) or achieve.
realize.descriptionEn: To realize means se rendre compte de, prendre conscience de, or comprendre.

rest.descriptionFr: Rester is a semi-false cognate. It usually means to stay or remain: Je suis restée à la maison - I stayed at the house. When it is used idiomatically, it is translated by rest: He refused to let the matter rest - Il refusait d'en rester là
rest.descriptionEn: The verb to rest in the sense of getting some rest is translated by se reposer: Elle ne se repose jamais - She never rests

reunion.descriptionFr: Une réunion can mean collection, gathering, raising (of money), or reunion.
reunion.descriptionEn: A reunion is une réunion, but note that it usually refers to a meeting of a group that has been separated for an extended period of time (e.g., class reunion, family reunion).

robe.descriptionFr: Une robe is a dress, frock, or gown.

sale.descriptionFr: Sale is an adjective - dirty. Saler means to salt.
sale.descriptionEn: A sale is une vente or un solde.

sympathetic.descriptionFr: Sympathique (often shortened to sympa) means nice, likeable, friendly, kindly.
sympathetic.descriptionEn: Sympathetic can be translated by compatissant or de sympathie.

type.descriptionFr: Un type is informal for a guy or bloke. In the normal register, it can mean type, kind, or epitome. Quel type de moto ? - What kind of motorbike? Le type de l'égoïsme - The epitome of selfishness.
type.descriptionEn: Type means un type, un genre, une espèce, une sorte, une marque, etc.

unique.descriptionFr: The French word unique means only when it precedes a noun (unique fille - only girl) and unique or one of a kind when it follows.
unique.descriptionEn: In English, unique means unique, inimitable, or exceptionnel.

zone.descriptionFr: Une zone usually means a zone or an area, but it can also refer to a slum.
